cons:

If you've been with the organization a while and are in line for a promotion, expect to have the word "Senior" placed before your current title and a bit more salary, but not much more in terms of real power and influence. When this happens, people leave, taking much organizational knowledge and know-how with them.

Leadership can be clique-y. High-level processes are often not as transparent as they can be. Things can stagnate at the executive level, stymieing what could otherwise be an even more creative, effective organization.

Decentralized nature of the organization is valuable but means a lack of programmatic oversight and unified vision. Many small fiefdoms in the field and at HQ. Agree with other reviews citing cronyism -- if the CEO and senior leadership consider you a favorite, you can do whatever you want; everyone else is part of the machine. review_title: Brilliant organisation; incredible potential if HR processes continue to improve
pros: Worked for this organisation as a member of field leadership for nearly a decade. Brilliant colleagues from both the NGO sector as well as diverse non-traditional, non-humanitarian backgrounds. Teams across the agency strive to make smart changes in the work they do as well as to internal structures & processes, meaning there is constantly a feeling of healthy self-critique and striving to do better. Of note are the impressive efforts to improve gender, diversity and inclusion initiatives throughout the agency, the refresh of procurement procedures that provide both flexibility and clarity to field operations, and the bottom-up decision-making processes that empower country programmes to feed into and (to a large extent) steer global priorities. Friendly and warm atmosphere at HQ offices as well as in the field makes you feel valued and connected.
cons: It often feels that key HR policies have interpreted values such as “transparent, structured and equitable” to mean “impersonal, rigid and robotic”. While I saw measurable improvements of some of these policies during my tenure, the organisation has far to go to rethink and redesign some key areas: staff retention, talent development and employee support systems are among the most lacking I have experienced in my career. This means your success is largely dependent on your relationship to your line manager, your personal networking skills, and your level of extraversion. Lack of proactive monitoring of many of our bright stars (expatriate, national, and HQ staff), coupled with lack of follow-up from HR have resulted in a massive brain drain which has severely handicapped the agency talent pipeline. Lack of clarity around benefits, surprisingly slow (internal and external) recruitment, and a dearth of in-person support for talent development and management in our country programmes means that country leaders are either ill-equipped to support their teams or else blocked when trying to make smart decision that will impact employee well-being and support country priorities.

My experience was that expertise is not valued unless you are in the top rung boy’s club or have ingratiated yourself with someone in that club. 

Current leadership of the marketing/fundraising department seemed to be hand-picked by the CEO and yet has no idea what they are doing. They don’t seem to like or respect fundraising, which they oversee. They also do not listen to the people they manage who DO have experience and expertise. 

People now have to work on a strategy that they know will not work for fundraising. Countless people have tried to educate leadership about what works and what the potential risks/consequences are of trying something completely different with no data or evidence to back it up. Instead of adjusting the strategy OR adjusting fundraising goals to account for the risk of trying something new, people are being held to even higher standards than before, with no realistic way of meeting those goals. This means that people can’t do their best work because of leadership mandates and are doomed to fail. This is hugely demoralizing. 

Leadership has created a toxic no feedback culture. They say they want feedback, but data and best practices are constantly ignored in preference of “gut feelings,” and people who challenge or question leadership in any way are branded as negative people who don’t see the vision. I’ve seen those people, who I believe are asking those questions to make the org better, be dismissed and then excluded from key conversations because they spoke up. 

The wrong people succeed. I’ve seen critical and high performing employees be laid off for reasons that seem suspicious at best, and others be demoted despite being universally beloved and hitting their goals. All the while, people who are friends with leadership keep climbing the ladder and those same people then hire their friends, whether they are qualified or not, or agencies they prefer without going through any RFP process. People who’ve made it into what I think of as ‘the club’ have VP level roles created for them out of thin air, whether they are necessary or not. 

There are no checks and balances. Valid and detailed complaints about these issues (and more) have been filed with HR with absolutely no recourse or consequences that I can tell. The upper rungs of the org can seemingly do no wrong. I personally lost faith in HR and leadership because of this, and I know I’m not the only one.

Many of these issues have been going on for a year or longer with no consequences. I and many others stuck it out for quite a while in the hopes that something would get better, that people would start listening, etc. But leadership doesn’t seem bothered by the extremely low morale and loss of many longtime employees. 

I am genuinely concerned about the future of the org. There seems to be reckless spending happening, all while a few people tell large groups of talented fundraisers to do things that go against best practice and internal historical knowledge and expertise. I would not be surprised to see many more people leave and possibly more layoffs due to low fundraising numbers caused by these new mandates strategies. 

I did not want to leave Mercy Corps. I truly loved my role there and I wanted to stay for 5+ more years. I loved my team like a family. But the stress, low morale and unreachable goals created by poor leadership was just too much after a year of dealing with the worst of it. I know my departure was a loss to the organization in terms of experience and historical knowledge - a loss that will sadly mostly be felt by colleagues I adored. It’s really sad to see a good place with so many good people turn into such a toxic and hostile workplace.
